ratioCategories.description: Measures the company's ability to meet short-term obligations using its most liquid assets.

ratios.name: Current Ratio
ratios.interpretation: At 2.01, the company has $2.01 in assets for every $1.00 of liability, indicating strong short-term solvency. This aligns with the source calculation [1].

ratios.name: Quick Ratio
ratios.interpretation: The ratio of 0.64 reveals a heavy reliance on inventory to meet obligations. Excluding the $1.34M in inventory [2], the company cannot cover current liabilities immediately.

ratios.name: Cash Ratio
ratios.interpretation: With only $155,134 in cash against $978,114 in liabilities [2][3], the company maintains a lean cash position, relying on cash flow and credit lines.

ratios.name: Working Capital
ratios.interpretation: Positive working capital of nearly $1M confirms operational stability, though much is tied up in inventory [4].

ratioCategories.description: Evaluates the company's ability to generate earnings relative to revenue and assets.

ratios.name: Gross Profit Margin
ratios.interpretation: The margin of 22.73% [5] is lower than the typical 30-35% for equipment dealers, potentially due to high cost of goods sold ($3.5M) or aggressive pricing.

ratios.name: Operating Profit Margin
ratios.interpretation: Strong operating efficiency. The company retains roughly 18.5 cents on the dollar before interest and taxes [5].

ratios.name: Net Profit Margin
ratios.interpretation: Net margin is healthy at 9.32% [5]. However, sources note a high effective tax rate (46.4%) due to lack of tax exemption decrees [6][7].

ratios.name: Return on Assets (ROA)
ratios.interpretation: Based on GAAP Net Income ($423k). The source reports a higher ROA (40%) using Pre-Tax income [8]. The high ROA is driven by fully depreciated fixed assets reducing the asset base [2].

ratios.name: Return on Equity (ROE)
ratios.interpretation: Exceptionally high ROE due to a relatively small equity base ($532k) compared to earnings. The source indicates a Pre-Tax ROE of 148% [8].

ratios.name: EBITDA Margin
ratios.interpretation: EBITDA of $789,577 [4] indicates strong operational cash generation potential before financial and tax impacts.

ratioCategories.description: Assesses the extent of the company's financing through debt versus equity.

ratios.name: Debt-to-Equity Ratio
ratios.interpretation: Highly leveraged at 2.70 [1]. The company uses significant debt ($1.43M), specifically Floorplan financing ($439k) [3], to fund operations relative to equity.

ratios.name: Debt-to-Assets Ratio
ratios.interpretation: 73% of the company's assets are financed by creditors, indicating a higher solvency risk profile.

ratios.name: Interest Coverage Ratio
ratios.interpretation: Excellent coverage. EBIT of $789k can cover the $66k interest expense almost 12 times over [9].

ratios.name: Equity Multiplier
ratios.interpretation: Indicates that the company owns $3.70 of assets for every $1 of equity, amplifying both risk and potential ROE.

ratioCategories.description: Measures how effectively the company uses its assets and manages its liabilities.

ratios.name: Asset Turnover
ratios.interpretation: The company generates $2.30 in sales for every $1 in assets [8]. This efficiency is artificially boosted because major fixed assets are fully depreciated [2].

ratios.name: Inventory Turnover
ratios.interpretation: Calculated using avg inventory ($1.09M). The source calculates 2.61 using ending inventory [10]. Turnover is slightly sluggish, consistent with holding high-value equipment.

ratios.name: Days Sales Outstanding
ratios.interpretation: Collections are efficient at ~37 days [10], beating the standard 45-day benchmark for B2B industrial sales.

ratios.name: Days Payable Outstanding
ratios.interpretation: The company takes ~49 days to pay vendors [11], effectively using supplier credit to finance the 37-day receivables cycle.

ratios.name: Accounts Receivable Turnover
ratios.interpretation: High turnover [10] indicates effective credit policies and collection procedures.

ratioCategories.description: Analyzes the cash generated relative to debt and obligations. (Note: Precise Operating Cash Flow (OCF) for the final audited figures is not explicitly detailed in the source text; values below are derived estimates based on Balance Sheet changes).

ratios.name: Operating Cash Flow Ratio
ratios.interpretation: Data Limitation: The specific OCF figure is cut off in source [12]. However, distinct increase in inventory ($510k) likely suppressed OCF despite strong Net Income.

ratios.name: Free Cash Flow
ratios.interpretation: Data Limitation: CapEx data is not explicitly detailed in the source snippets for the Rev156-3 version.

ratios.name: Cash Flow to Debt Ratio
ratios.interpretation: Data Limitation: Cannot be precisely calculated from source text. Total Debt includes significant Floorplan ($439k) and Notes Payable.

overallAnalysis: Based on the 2024 Audited Financial Statements (Rev156-1/3), NLTS-PR demonstrates a high-return, high-leverage business model. The company is highly profitable with an ROE of 79% (GAAP basis) and strong Interest Coverage (11.93x). However, liquidity is mixed; while the Current Ratio is safe (2.01), the Quick Ratio (0.64) highlights a significant dependance on moving inventory to meet obligations. The balance sheet reflects a mature asset base where fixed assets are fully depreciated (Net Book Value $0), artificially inflating efficiency ratios like Asset Turnover and ROA. A critical finding is the high effective tax rate (approx. 46%) impacting Net Margins, suggesting a need for tax structure optimization (Act 60). The discrepancy in inventory turnover calculations suggests management should focus on optimizing stock levels ($1.34M) to free up cash flow.
